claim: If admissions to the hospital had been suspended for six months during 1991, fewer patients with normal immunoglobulin A levels would have been captured in the records after January 1, 1990.
extra_info: normal Ig A level refers to IGA > 80 AND IGA < 500; came to the hospital after 1990/1/1 refers to YEAR(`First Date`) > = 1990;
reasoning: This is a counterfactual claim. It describes a hypothetical scenario ('If admissions to the hospital had been suspended for six months during 1991') and asks what would have happened under those imagined circumstances. The database only records what actually happened, not what would have happened if hospital admissions had been suspended. Counterfactual claims cannot be verified from historical data.

content.text:
This claim describes a hypothetical "what if" scenario: "If admissions to the hospital had been suspended for six months during 1991..." This is a counterfactual claim - it asks about what would have happened under imagined circumstances that didn't actually occur.

According to my classification rules, counterfactual claims that describe hypothetical scenarios cannot be verified from a database that only records what actually happened. The database contains records of actual events, not simulations of alternative timelines.

The database only records what actually happened, not what would have happened if hospital admissions had been suspended. Counterfactual claims cannot be verified from historical data."}
